comment.author: 52325611@N05
comment._content: See "Columbia River Highway" at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historic_Columbia_River_Highway for more information.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Amos Tuck French (Jul. 20, 1863 - Nov. 15, 1941), banker and businessman, was also director of the Northern Pacific Railway, see www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=81626749 NYT, November 25, 1914 A. D. Charlton and Hazen J. Titus were managers of the Northern Pacific Railway, a photo with them is here: See comments there. Mrs. French Vanderbilt (Ellen (Elsie) Tuck French Vanderbilt Astor, who married first Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt I then divorced) was the sister of Amos T. French.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: John Yeon: Portland millionnaire and road builder Jean Baptiste Yeon (also known as John B. Yeon, 1865–1928) (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_B._Yeon) According to www.oregonstateparks.org/index.cfm?do=parkPage.dsp_parkHi..., "he was a prime supporter of the Columbia River Highway. As Multnomah County Roadmaster from 1913 to 1917, Yeon supervised initial construction of the highway, complimenting his salary and backing the project financially. He served on the Oregon Highway Commission in the years 1920-1923." He was also involved in the railroad business, see Lincoln County leader., April 26, 1918, Image 1, col. 4, "JOHN B. YEON IN CHARGE OF R.R. WORK". Other photo of him: www.portlandhikers.org/forum/download/file.php?id=22308&a... and in photos.oregonlive.com/photo-essay/2013/09/historic_columb....

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: A March 17, 1916 newspaper account, accompanied by a photo of a much younger Mrs. Elsie French Vanderbilt: "HIGHWAY ENTHRALLS NEW YORK SOCIETY Mrs. Alfred G. Vanderbilt Is Member of Motor Party Over Scenic Route. RETURN VISIT PROMISED Prominent Banker Declares Mediterranean Vistas Are Eclipsed and All Express Desire to See Summer Foliage. Charmed by a trip over the Columbia River Highway yesterday. Mrs. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt. Mr. and Mrs. Amos Tuck French, Lawrence Perkins, and Miss Hazel J. Titus, all of New York City, and members of the smartest set of Gotham, became enamored of Oregon scenery and resolved to return here this Summer." Howard and La Velle Charlton are mentioned as being on the trip, as well as Mr. and Mrs. A.D. Charlton and John Yeon. "Miss Hazel J. Titus" could be a mistaken identification of Hazen J. Titus, or it could be a woman in the second car. oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1916-03-17/ed-1/se... A short entry on Elsie French Vanderbilt: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Gwynne_Vanderbilt_I#Elsie_Fr... Mrs. Amos French is holding an oblong object that says Northern Pacific on it. According to the caption of the photo on another site, "Portland citizen John Yeon is driving the first car (an air-cooled Franklin) with his passenger Mrs. French Vanderbilt. Some of her relatives and friends join the party. Yeon, a wealthy lumberman, had a special interest in the highway. He volunteered as Multnomah County's road master for $1 a year to supervise its construction." www.oldoregonphotos.com/subject/canyons-gorges-valleys/ne...

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] Not sure, but I believe the Ellen French who married the Astor was a niece of the woman in the photo.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] You are right. That Elsie Tuck French Vanderbilt would be the later Mrs. Astor is written in www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=81626749, but is mistaken. Obviously somebody mashed her up with Ellen Tuck "Tucky" French (December 10, 1915 — September 5, 1974), who married John Jacob Astor VI in 1934 and who was a granddaughter of Amos Tuck French (according to www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=94178655). The later husband of Elsie French Vanderbilt was Paul Fitzsimons, they married in 1919, see The Washington times., April 20, 1919, NATIONAL EDITION, The American Weekly Section, Image 23. And the Morning Oregonian confused the photo in its issue of March 17, 1916 (oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1916-03-17/ed-1/se...). The woman shown there is not Elsie French Vanderbilt, but Margaret Emerson Vanderbilt, the second wife of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt. The same photo is depicted in The Spokesman-Review - 27. Juni 1915 with the correct caption (and with a photo of Elsie French Vanderbilt on the same page). See also the two women in the Bismarck daily tribune., September 02, 1913, Image 6.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: A color photo of 1915 Franklin, same or similar to the car in front: www.jaylenosgarage.com/cars/franklin/1915-franklin/#item=...

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Lots of misinformation on the internet.. and in contemporary newspapers, too. That is definitely the later Mrs. A.G. Vanderbilt pictured in the Oregonian. Here's a 1915 portrait of the Mrs. Vanderbilt pictured here: www.tnportraits.org/vanderbilt-ef-no7.htm

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Thanks to both of you for working so hard to sort out the identities given the misinformation provided in the newspapers. We'll add some of this information to the record the next time we update.
